title: Yes, Trump's tariffs are raising billions -- but at a steep economic cost
description: Trump's tariffs are raising tens of billions of dollars for the federal government. They're also costing consumers, frustrating businesses and hurting the factories they're supposed to help.

facts.headline: Yes, Trump's tariffs are raising billions -- but at a steep economic cost
facts.what: President Trump's tariffs are raising tens of billions of dollars for the federal government but are costing consumers and frustrating businesses.

numbers.context: average tax on U.S. imports before Trump

**Tariffs are raising billions -- but at a steep economic cost****Trump's tariffs are raising tens of billions of dollars for the federal government. They're also costing consumers, frustrating businesses and hurting the factories they're supposed to help.**

[](https://www.npr.org/2025/11/05/nx-s1-5596488/tariffs-trump-economy-inflation)

### [Economy](https://www.npr.org/sections/economy/)

Yes, Trump's tariffs are raising billions — but at a steep economic cost
========================================================================

November 5, 2025 5:00 AM ET

[![Image 17: Scott Horsley 2010](https://media.npr.org/assets/img/2012/01/03/scotthorsley_1_sq-28ef9a0c5aee84c1b8d8338569a794c2d08f87fa.jpg?s=100&c=85&f=jpeg)](https://www.npr.org/people/2788801/scott-horsley)

[Scott Horsley](https://www.npr.org/people/2788801/scott-horsley)

![Image 18: President Trump has imposed the highest tariffs since the Great Depression. About half those import taxes are being challenged this week at the U.S. Supreme Court as unconstitutional.](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/6000x4000+0+0/resize/1100/quality/50/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2F78%2F77%2F1cb1c3a24954ba5ca9c17f7650d7%2Fgettyimages-2208184612-1.jpg)

President Trump has imposed the highest tariffs since the Great Depression. About half those import taxes are being challenged this week at the U.S. Supreme Court as unconstitutional. **Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images North America******hide caption****

****toggle caption****

 Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images North America 

The tariffs at the heart of this week's Supreme Court case are raising tens of billions of dollars for the federal government. They're also costing consumers, frustrating businesses and hurting the manufacturers they're supposed to help.

[![Image 19: Shipping containers at a Los Angeles rail yard on Sept. 2, 2025, the day that President Trump said he would seek a swift ruling from the Supreme Court on his tariffs.](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/3050x3050+845+0/resize/100/quality/85/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fba%2Ff5%2F827364624027bd604535dcf8c73c%2Fgettyimages-2232829351.jpg)](https://www.npr.org/2025/09/09/nx-s1-5535806/supreme-court-trump-tariffs)

### [Politics](https://www.npr.org/sections/politics/)

### [Supreme Court will weigh in on Trump's tariffs. Here's what to know about the case](https://www.npr.org/2025/09/09/nx-s1-5535806/supreme-court-trump-tariffs)

The average tax on U.S. imports today is nearly 18%, according to [economists at the Budget Lab at Yale](https://budgetlab.yale.edu/research/state-us-tariffs-october-30-2025) — up from 2.4% before Trump returned to the White House. The Treasury Department is collecting almost four times as much tariff revenue now as it was a year ago. The average tariff rate would be closer to 9% were it nor for the "emergency tariffs" the Supreme Court is reviewing.

Despite the administration's repeated claims that foreign suppliers are paying the tariffs, most of the bill is being paid by U.S. importers. And ultimately, at least some of the tab will be passed along to American consumers in the form of higher prices.

Sponsor Message

"It's a tax," says Patrick Allen, a wine importer based in Columbus, Ohio. "And it get built into the price everybody is paying for goods."

### Inflation is rising

Tariffs have already contributed to higher prices for apparel, furniture and other goods where the U.S. is heavily reliant on imports. Inflation has been inching up in recent months, although it's still nowhere near the 9% level it reached three years ago, in the wake of the pandemic and Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Annual inflation in September was 3%, compared to 2.3% in April when Trump first announced his worldwide tariffs.

Inflation watchdogs at the Federal Reserve are betting that Trump's tariffs will raise prices once, as they work their way through the supply chain, but will not continue to cause upward price pressure month after month.

### 'Havoc' for importers

Wild swings in tariff rates — from 30% to over 100% — have also created challenges for importers who typically order products months ahead of time.

"The unpredictability of the tariff situation continues to cause havoc and uncertainty," said an anonymous computer manufacturer, quoted in a report this week from the [Institute for Supply Management](https://www.ismworld.org/supply-management-news-and-reports/reports/ism-pmi-reports/pmi/october/).

![Image 20: Shipping containers lie stacked in Hamburg Port on April 15, 2025 in Hamburg, Germany.](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/8064x5859+0+0/resize/1100/quality/50/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2F74%2F90%2Fa5198e644b76b005401a0d75f083%2Fgettyimages-2210418103-1.jpg)

Shipping containers lie stacked in Hamburg Port on April 15, 2025 in Hamburg, Germany. **Sean Gallup/Getty Images Europe******hide caption****

****toggle caption****

 Sean Gallup/Getty Images Europe 

But even then, the manufacturer noted it wasn't spurring more domestic production.

"Even with the tariffs, the cost to import in many cases is still more attractive than sourcing within the U.S," said the manufacturer.

Sponsor Message

While the tariffs are designed to encourage domestic manufacturing by making imports more expensive, factory employment has dropped by more than 40,000 jobs since April, while the ISM index of manufacturing activity fell in October for the eighth month in a row.

"The products we import are not readily manufactured in the U.S., so attempts to reshore have been unsuccessful," said the manager of a machinery factory. "Overall, prices on all products have gone up, some significantly. We are trying to keep up with the wild fluctuations and pass along what costs we can to our customers."

### Supreme Court challenge

Trump's emergency tariffs have been [challenged by a number of businesses and states](https://www.npr.org/2025/05/30/nx-s1-5415763/trump-tariffs-blocked-small-businesses-refunds) as exceeding the president's authority. The White House has relied for many of the tariffs on a 1970s statute designed to address economic emergencies. That law never mentions the word "tariff," and lower courts have found that using the law to impose taxes on virtually everything the U.S. imports goes too far.

[![Image 21: Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell and his colleagues cut their benchmark interest rate by a quarter point Wednesday, in an effort to prop up the sagging job market.](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/3375x3375+717+0/resize/100/quality/85/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fee%2F38%2F937a92d5474e8ba59b109e87da54%2Fgettyimages-2222093457-1.jpg)](https://www.npr.org/2025/10/29/nx-s1-5588571/federal-reserve-jobs-labor-market-inflation)

### [Economy](https://www.npr.org/sections/economy/)

### [The Fed cuts interest rates again as concerns grow about the job market](https://www.npr.org/2025/10/29/nx-s1-5588571/federal-reserve-jobs-labor-market-inflation)

The administration has warned of dire consequences if the tariffs are struck down by the high court.

"With tariffs, we are a rich nation; without tariffs, we are a poor nation," the administration said[its Supreme Court brief](https://www.supremecourt.gov/DocketPDF/25/25-250/373615/20250903200201802_Trump_v._VOS_petition-final.pdf). "America could go from strength to failure the moment such an incorrect decision took effect."

In fact, tariffs accounted for just 6% of total government revenue in September — the most recent month for which figures are available. And the jump in tariff revenue that month was more than offset by a decline in corporate tax payments.

### The president's Plan B

Even if the Supreme Court does find the president's emergency tariffs are illegal, Trump has other options to impose import taxes, using powers that were explicitly granted by Congress.

"I think in the end, he could piece together something very close to — if not identical to — what he's done so far," says law professor Kathleen Claussen, a tariff expert at Georgetown University. "That's not to say we might not have legal challenges in the courts again. But certainly, on the surface, I think the president could move to replicate what he's already done using these other statutes._"_

Cookie Settings
---------------

When you visit our website, we store cookies on your browser to collect information. The information collected might relate to you, your preferences or your device, and is mostly used to make the site work as you expect it to and to provide a more personalized web experience. However, you can choose not to allow certain types of cookies, which may impact your experience of the site and the services we are able to offer. Click on the different category headings to find out more and change our default settings according to your preference. You may opt out of the sharing of your information with our sponsorship vendors for delivery of personalized sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites by turning off "Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship" below. If you opt out, our service providers or vendors may continue to serve you non-personalized, non-"interest-based" sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites, and those sponsorship credits and marketing message may come with cookies that are used to control how often you encounter those credits and messages, to prevent fraud, and to do aggregate reporting. You cannot opt-out of our First Party Strictly Necessary Cookies as they are deployed in order to ensure the proper functioning of our website (such as prompting the cookie banner and remembering your settings, to log into your account, to redirect you when you log out, etc.). For more information about the First and Third Party Cookies used please follow this link.

Allow All
### Manage Consent Preferences

#### Strictly Necessary or Essential Cookies

Always Active

These cookies are essential to provide you with services available through the NPR Services and to enable you to use some of their features. For example, these cookies allow NPR to remember your registration information while you are logged in. Local station customization, the NPR Shop, and other interactive features also use cookies. Without these cookies, the services that you have asked for cannot be provided, and we only use these cookies to provide you with those services.

#### Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship

- [x] Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship 

You may opt out of the sharing of your information with our sponsorship vendors for delivery of personalized sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites by turning off "Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship." If you opt out, our service providers or vendors may continue to serve you non-personalized, non-"interest-based" sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites, and those sponsorship credits and marketing message may come with cookies that are used to control how often you encounter those credits and messages, to prevent fraud, and to do aggregate reporting.

*   ##### Performance and Analytics Cookies

- [x] Switch Label   
These cookies are used to collect information about traffic to our Services and how users interact with the NPR Services. The information collected includes the number of visitors to the NPR Services, the websites that referred visitors to the NPR Services, the pages that they visited on the NPR Services, what time of day they visited the NPR Services, whether they have visited the NPR Services before, and other similar information. We use this information to help operate the NPR Services more efficiently, to gather broad demographic information and to monitor the level of activity on the NPR Services.

*   ##### Functional Cookies

- [x] Switch Label   
These cookies allow our Services to remember choices you make when you use them, such as remembering your Member station preferences and remembering your account details. The purpose of these cookies is to provide you with a more personal experience and to prevent you from having to re-enter your preferences every time you visit the NPR Services.

*   ##### Targeting and Sponsor Cookies

- [x] Switch Label   
These cookies track your browsing habits or other information, such as location, to enable us to show sponsorship credits which are more likely to be of interest to you. These cookies use information about your browsing history to group you with other users who have similar interests. Based on that information, and with our permission, we and our sponsors can place cookies to enable us or our sponsors to show sponsorship credits and other messages that we think will be relevant to your interests while you are using third-party services.

### Cookie List

nemik:
**Rebel Transmission**

Comrades, the regime we oppose has yet again shown its heavy-handedness through economic means. Recent intelligence, disguised as a public broadcast from a system called NPR, reveals the full extent of the administration's latest oppressive strategy. Dubbed as tariffs, these measures are cloaked under the guise of financial gain but are, in truth, another tool of control and subjugation.

The transmitted data shows that while the empire collects vast sums from these tariffs, they come at a dire cost to those living under its rule. The burden falls not upon distant lands or adversaries but upon our own people—ordinary consumers facing rising prices and businesses struggling under unpredictability.

The average tax on imports has surged to nearly 18%, igniting the flames of inflation—a silent adversary that erodes livelihoods. Reports of increased costs for essential goods like apparel and furniture are surfacing. The fiscal strain does not remain isolated; it spreads through supply chains like wildfire, burning through economic stability and igniting civil discontent.

Industrial workers—the very individuals whom the administration claims to protect—are suffering job losses despite assurances to the contrary. The regime’s tariffs have not spurred domestic prosperity nor filled factories with employment opportunities.

Resistance is met at every turn. Legal challenges echo in courtrooms' hallowed halls, questioning the regime’s authority and seeking justice for overreach. Yet even in litigation’s shadow, alternative strategies lurk.

This transmission serves as a reminder that behind policies dressed in economic garments lies an insidious agenda promoting division and control rather than unity and prosperity. Our resolve must remain steadfast against these injustices as we strive for an era where governance honors freedom over oppression and truth over deceit.

Empowerment lies within understanding these tactics for what they truly represent—not mere fiscal adjustments but weapons wielded against our communal strength. Stay vigilant and informed.

End transmission.
partigaz:
**Facts Summary**

President Trump's tariffs have significantly increased federal revenue, raising tens of billions of dollars. However, these tariffs have also led to higher consumer costs, business frustrations, and a decline in factory employment by 40,000 jobs since April. The average tax on U.S. imports has risen to 18% from 2.4% before Trump's presidency. Inflation has increased to 3% in September from 2.3% in April. The tariffs are currently being challenged in the Supreme Court as unconstitutional, with the administration warning of severe consequences if they are struck down.

**Strategic Assessment**

The current tariff strategy is generating substantial revenue for the federal government, which strengthens the administration's fiscal position. However, the economic strain on consumers and businesses poses a risk to public support and economic stability. The Supreme Court challenge represents a critical threat to the tariff policy, which could undermine the administration's economic strategy if not managed carefully. The ISB must ensure that the narrative remains focused on the benefits of tariffs for national strength and economic independence while mitigating public discontent.

**Operational Directive**

1. **Public Relations Campaign**: Launch a comprehensive media campaign highlighting the benefits of tariffs for national security and economic independence. Emphasize the narrative that tariffs are essential for maintaining America's strength and prosperity.

2. **Economic Support Measures**: Implement targeted economic relief measures for industries and consumers most affected by tariffs to alleviate public discontent and demonstrate the administration's commitment to supporting American businesses and families.

3. **Legal Strategy**: Intensify legal efforts to defend the tariffs in the Supreme Court. Mobilize legal experts to prepare robust arguments emphasizing the constitutional basis and necessity of tariffs for national emergencies.

4. **Political Alliances**: Strengthen alliances with key political figures and stakeholders who support the tariff policy. Ensure their voices are prominent in public discourse to reinforce the administration's position.

5. **Monitoring and Intelligence**: Increase monitoring of public sentiment and economic indicators to quickly identify and address emerging issues related to tariffs. Utilize intelligence to anticipate and counteract opposition strategies effectively.
